speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I have a brief statement, and then I’ll be happy to respond to your questions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The job market remains strong, the economy continues to expand, and inflation appears to be moving toward the FOMC’s 2 percent longer-run goal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As you already know, we decided today to raise the target rate for the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point, bringing it to 1½ to 1¾ percent.1 This decision marks another step in the ongoing process of gradually scaling back monetary policy accommodation—a process that has been under way for several years now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Job gains averaged 240,000 per month over the past three months, well above the pace needed in the longer run to absorb new entrants into the labor force.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate remained low in February at 4.1 percent, while the labor force participation rate moved higher.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Over the past four years, the participation rate has remained roughly unchanged.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s a sign of improvement, given that the aging of our population is putting downward pressure on the participation rate, and we expect that the job market will remain strong.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Although the growth rates of household spending and business investment appear to have moderated early this year, gains in the fourth quarter were strong and the fundamentals underpinning demand remain solid.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Indeed, the economic outlook has strengthened in recent months.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Several factors are supporting the outlook: Fiscal policy has become more stimulative, ongoing job gains are boosting incomes and confidence, foreign growth is on a firm trajectory, and overall financial conditions remain accommodative.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: 1 Chairman Powell intended to say that the Committee had raised the target “range” for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Against this backdrop, inflation remains below our 2 percent longer-run objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Overall consumer prices, as measured by the price index for personal consumption expenditures, increased 1.7 percent in the 12 months ending in January.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The core price index, which excludes the prices of energy and food and is typically a better indicator of future inflation, rose 1.5 percent over the same period.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: However, as we have noted for some time, the shortfall of inflation from 2 percent reflects, at least partly, some unusual price declines that occurred nearly a year ago.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In coming months, as those earlier declines drop out of the calculation, inflation should move up closer to 2 percent and stabilize around that level over the medium term.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Of course, various forces will continue to affect inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: At times it may be above 2 percent, just as at times it may be below.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Our inflation objective is symmetric in the sense that we are trying to prevent persistent deviations from 2 percent in either direction.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Based on the projections that Committee participants submitted for this meeting, the median projection for the growth of inflation-adjusted GDP is 2.7 percent this year, 2.4 percent next year, and 2 percent in 2020, a bit above its estimated longer-run rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The median projection for unemployment—for the unemployment rate stands at 3.8 percent in the fourth quarter of this year and runs at 3.6 percent over the next two years, almost a percentage point below the median estimate of its longer-run normal rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Finally, the median inflation projection is 1.9 percent this year, 2 percent next year, and 2.1 percent in 2020.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Compared with the projections made in December, real GDP growth is stronger, the unemployment rate is lower, and inflation is slightly higher.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As I noted earlier, today’s decision to raise the federal funds rate is another step in the process of gradually scaling back monetary policy accommodation as the economic expansion March 21, 2018 continues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This gradual process has been under way for more than two years, and it has Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL served—and should continue to serve—the economy well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In making our policy decisions over the next few years, we will continue to aim for inflation of 2 percent while sustaining the economic expansion and a strong labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In the Committee’s view, further gradual increases in the federal funds rate will best promote these goals.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: By contrast, raising rates too slowly would raise the risk that monetary policy would need to tighten abruptly down the road, which could jeopardize the economic expansion.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: At the same time, we want to avoid inflation running persistently below our objective, which could leave us with less scope to counter an economic downturn in the future.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Participants’ projections of the appropriate path for the federal funds rate reflect our gradual approach.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The median projection for the federal funds rate is 2.1 percent at the end of this year, 2.9 percent at the end of 2019, and 3.4 percent at the end of 2020.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: By 2020, the median federal funds rate is modestly above its estimated longer-run trend.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Most participants revised up their projections since December, although the median projection for this year did not change.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The medians for 2019 and 2020 are somewhat higher than in December.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Of course, we’ll be watching how the economy evolves in the months and years ahead relative to our maximum employment and price stability objectives.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If the outlook changes, we will adjust monetary policy appropriately.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Finally, I’ll note that our program for reducing our balance sheet, which began in October, is proceeding smoothly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Barring a very significant and unexpected weakening in the outlook, we do not intend to alter this program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As we’ve said, changing the target range for the federal funds rate is our primary means of adjusting the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As always, the Committee would be prepared to use its full range of tools if future economic conditions March 21, 2018 were to warrant a more accommodative monetary policy than can be achieved solely by reducing Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Thank you, and I’ll be happy to take your questions now.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Mr. Chairman—right, the microphone.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Mr. Chairman, welcome.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Interesting changes in the forecast.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: A higher growth forecast a full point above the long run, lower unemployment seven-tenths below the long run, and yet very little change in inflation.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: What does that say about what you and the Committee believe about the inflation dynamic?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And how is it that, in that context, you justify three rate hikes this year—and I sense there’ll be three next year—and a full $600 billion, I guess, annual rate decline in the balance sheet?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Where's your biggest concern here?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Is it in overkill when it comes to rates or underkill?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, you’re right that the outlook did improve, as I mentioned and as you—as was in your question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The Committee’s estimates of growth went up, the Committee’s estimates of unemployment went down, and there was a very slight increase in inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I think that reflects, essentially—if you think back to the era after the crisis, unemployment was 10 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s now 4.1 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You’ve only seen very gradual upward pressures on inflation and wages despite that very large increase.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that suggests that the relationship between changes in slack and inflation is not so tight.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But, it has diminished, but it’s still there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I think when you see those small changes in unemployment, that simply reflects the, you know, the flatness of the Phillips curve, if you will.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And your biggest concern or your biggest risk here—is it doing too much, doing too little?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, I think we’re trying to, we’re trying to be, to take the middle ground there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, you know, on the one hand, the risk would be that we wait too March 21, 2018 long, and then we have to raise rates quickly, and that foreshortens the expansion.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL want to do that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The—on the other side, if we—if we raise rates too quickly, inflation, then, really doesn’t get sustainably up to 2 percent, and, that will hurt us going forward.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We need that, and it’s, you know, we need to make sure that inflation expectations are anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’re trying to take that middle ground, and the Committee continues to believe that the middle ground consists of further gradual increases in the federal funds rate as long as the economy is broadly on this path.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: I’m Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Chair Powell, I want to ask about the symmetric inflation target—what you outlined in your remarks as preventing persistent deviations.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: I want to understand what symmetry means in the context of inflation being allowed to run above the 2 percent target now that that’s part of the projection for—at least for core PCE next year.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: How do you define symmetric relative to the experience of the past five years?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Would the Fed be willing to accept the type of overshoot of its target as it has seen during the undershoot?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And how high above 2 percent is too high to maintain a target that is symmetric?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Is it 2¼, 2½, 2¾?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And also, for how long?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, so as you noted, the—what we’ve said in the longer-run statement of goals and monetary policy strategy is that we would be concerned with sustained or persistent deviations of inflation either above or below.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve also said—in minutes and in speeches and things like that—that that is a symmetric objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, that’s how we think of it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, I think it’s—I wouldn’t characterize what we’ve done over the last five years as tolerating, you know, an undershoot of inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We were always pushing toward 2 percent, and I think that is how we look at it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I can’t give you an exact number.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It just, you know, it, we haven’t agreed on that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It just is that we’re always going to be seeking 2 percent March 21, 2018 inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And in doing that, we’re going to be considering, by the way, the other side of the Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL mandate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we have to balance that against the deviation of employment from—unemployment from its goal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And—and also, just the duration of it as well.

speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA
sentence: Hi, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA
sentence: Jim Puzzanghera with the L.A. Times.

speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA
sentence: Even with the extra fiscal stimulus of the tax cuts, your median growth projection is just up to 2.7 percent, and then—this year—and then drops back down to 2 percent by 2020.

speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA
sentence: Is the continued talk in Washington about tax cuts bringing growth to 3 percent or higher on a sustained basis overselling their potential impact?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, let me say what that really is.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the Summary of Economic Projections is really a compilation of the individual rate forecasts.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The Committee made really one decision at this meeting, and that was to raise the federal funds rate by 25 basis points.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The Summary of Economic Projections is individual forecasts compiled and written down.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you’ve identified the median as 2.7 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would—and that’s an interesting statistic.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would also say that the central tendency is interesting.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The full range is interesting.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So you have a range of views around the table.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: One of the great benefits of our system is that we do have Reserve Banks with their own staffs and Governors with different views, and so we discuss these things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the Committee doesn’t vote or agree upon the medians, so you’re going to have a range of views.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s really all I can say—2.7 just happens to be the median for ’18, but it doesn’t really say, you know, what we think is possible.

speaker: JIM PUZZANGHERA
sentence: But do you think you can get to 3 percent on a sustained basis?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, I would say it’s hard to say, but it would take—you know, that is well above almost all estimates, current estimates of potential long-run growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It March 21, 2018 would take, you know, significant increases in productivity and labor force participation to Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL get there.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Hi, Jeanna Smialek with Bloomberg News.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: So obviously you guys reduced your NAIRU estimates slightly today, but if you continue to see job gains around 200,000 a month, primary labor participation rising slightly, pretty sustainably, you know, moderate wage increases, at what point are you guys going to start to question whether you’re actually overshooting full employment?

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: And, if you start to question that, how is that going to impact policy?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I guess I’d start by saying that the natural rate of unemployment is not something that we can observe directly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We look at a wide range of indicators on that—you know, 15 or 20 of them at least.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And also, I think we all understand that any point estimate is surrounded by very wide uncertainty bands.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So as the—as the actual unemployment rate has declined from 10 percent to 4.1 percent, the Committee’s median estimate of the natural rate of unemployment has also declined by a full percentage point.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the Committee—and, I think, people—are generally influenced by data.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As they see unemployment going lower, they’re looking at a variety of aspects of the labor market, including wage inflation and price inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I don’t think we, we—we’re mindful of the uncertainty of that, and we’ll be looking at that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, as—if inflation—if unemployment does continue to go down, we’ll continue to do that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned earlier, there is no—there’s no sense in the data that we’re on the cusp of an acceleration of inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We have seen moderate increases in wages and price inflation, and we seem to be seeing more of that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ll be alert to that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I guess the idea—the theory would be that if you get below the sustainable rate of unemployment for a sustained March 21, 2018 period, you would see an acceleration of inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we would know that then, and we’re very Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL alert to it, but it’s not something we observe at the present.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: Thanks very much.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: Sam Fleming from Financial Times.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: You and other policymakers have talked about headwinds turning into tailwinds recently.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: Does that imply that you think now a higher neutral rate of interest is operative in the U.S. economy, and how would you assess the implications for monetary policy?

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: And second question—this is obviously your first press conference, so it’s a little early to ask this question, but would you like to do this more often?

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Longer-run values like the neutral rate of interest, the natural rate of unemployment, the potential growth rate of the economy are pinned down by slow-moving forces over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So they don’t—they don’t move around very much.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I wouldn’t expect the Committee’s, you know, predictions or projections or estimates of those values to move quickly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They’ll move slowly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So is it possible that the neutral rate of interest would move up because of, for example, greater fiscal expansion?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There’s literature that says that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There’s—there are reasons that that might be the case.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In fact, it did tick up one-tenth, as you all know, in the—in the median at this time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But it’s—I think, generally speaking, the Committee sees the neutral rate of interest as still quite low and is not—is not seeing it as having moved up and is open to the possibility that it will.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: And press conferences?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Ah, press conferences.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s something that I’m going to be carefully considering.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I have not made a decision about it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I are committed to communicating as clearly as possible about what we’re doing and why we’re doing it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would want to think very carefully about it and make sure that no one would take more March 21, 2018 frequent press conferences as a signal of the path of policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so, it is something that I’ll be Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL thinking about.

speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO
sentence: Adam Shapiro with the Fox Business Network.

speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO
sentence: You brought up the fiscal stimulus and the impact it’s having, and I was curious, how is the change in the federal budget deficit—because the stimulus is coming with great debt—has it changed your approach to how many securities you’re going to allow to roll off the balance sheet, and is there a level of Treasury supply at which the Fed would consider adjusting its balance sheet roll-off, given how much the U.S. government’s going to have to borrow going forward?

speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO
sentence: And, then a second question, things beyond your control—the President is expected to announce new tariffs against China, and does the Committee discuss what potential impacts that could have in regards to inflation?

speaker: ADAM SHAPIRO
sentence: And do you have a timeline as to how you would respond to that?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, in terms of the balance sheet, we’ve said that, you know, we carefully developed this plan.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We carefully socialized it in a series of meetings last year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We announced it, and we said we wouldn’t change it, really, unless there were a significant downturn that required, you know, meaningful reductions in interest rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I have no inclination to revisit that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re going to use monetary policy as the principle tool of adjusting, you know, our policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, on the second question, on tariffs, a number of participants in this FOMC did bring up the issue of tariffs, and if I could summarize what came out of that, it was, first, that there’s no thought, I think, that changes in trade policy should have any effect on the current outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Second thing is, I would say, is that a number of participants reported in—about their conversations with business leaders around the country and reported that trade policy has become a concern going forward for that group.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Marty Crutsinger with the Associated Press.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: You talked about the fact that the Summary of Economic Projections is based on the outlook of all the members of the FOMC.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Can you tell us anything, though, about the staff forecast and how that was impacted by the—we had a $1½ trillion tax cut, we’ve had $300 billion in increased government spending—the staff forecast that you’re working with, are those reflected—how were they impacted by that?

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: And how did that impact the discussions?

speaker: CHAIRIMAN POWELL
sentence: So we look at the staff forecasts and the Board forecasts—and, by the way, there are 12 excellent Reserve Bank staffs who have their own views and do their own work—we look at those as informing the decisions of the policymakers.

speaker: CHAIRIMAN POWELL
sentence: So—and it’s really the policymakers’ views that we talk about in the SEP. We don’t—we don’t, you know, talk about the staff forecast.

speaker: CHAIRIMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s a particular thing under—done under particular rules and circumstances.

speaker: CHAIRIMAN POWELL
sentence: And, really, it’s the policymakers that then take that as input and create their forecasts, which are what drive policy.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: That had no impact, though?

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: It’s such a—that’s a major increase in government stimulus that you’re—that had to have had an impact on the discussions, I would think, though.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Well, the—you’re right.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So fiscal stimulus is a, you know, a meaningful input into, you know, into the SEP and particularly in the changes over the course of last year and this year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And individual policymakers went through, with their staffs, a range of estimates, a range of literature, and did their own thinking and came up with their own estimates and submitted those as their Summary of Economic Projections—as their projections.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Those are not the staff’s projections.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Those are our projections.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Heather Long, Washington Post.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: I—what will it take to get to four rate hikes this year?

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: It’s clear from the dot plot that many members do think four would be appropriate, but clearly something was holding a number of the FOMC members back.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Is it concerns about these potential trade tariffs that are going into effect?

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Is it just that people want to wait and see a little longer before they raise?

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Can you give us some more insight into why people didn’t go to four this time—the median—even though the economic projections look very healthy?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would go back to the thought that, you know, we made one decision at this meeting, and that decision was to raise the federal funds rate by 25 basis points.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The projections are really just individual projections that are submitted and then compiled.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, you’re mentioning the median as being, you know, three and four being close, but, you know, I think, like any set of forecasts, those forecasts will change over time, and they’ll change depending on the way the outlook for the economy changes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s really all I can say.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It could change up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It could change down.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t want to—for now, these are the best forecasts that people could make, and, you know, it could be that if the economy’s a little bit stronger or a little bit weaker, then the path could be a little less gradual or a little more gradual.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: So it wasn’t one factor that was pulling at the heart of the discussion?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Not, no.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: Mr. Chairman, a quick follow on the trade question, and then a productivity question.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: On trade, what would have to happen in policy—and, in particular, in potential retaliation from countries around the world—for trade policy to become a concern for the Committee’s outlook?

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: And then, the second question is, you mentioned productivity growth March 21, 2018 earlier.

speaker: JIM TANKERSLEY
sentence: What’s your current assessment of the path of productivity growth, and has anything in Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL policy—any policy change in recent months changed that assessment?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, for trade, what I mentioned is that our FOMC participants reported in that they had heard, you know, concerns, which were relatively new, about—about future trade actions, really.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And they’re seeing it as a risk-to-the-outlook kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So—and the kind of things people are talking about would be, you know, more widespread retaliation and more widespread actions back-and-forth kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I can’t be any more specific than that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In terms of productivity—productivity, as I’m sure you know, has been very weak since the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s averaged only about 0.5 percent a year for the last six years, I guess.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s well below, you know, longer-run averages, and it would certainly be a good thing to see it move up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It has moved up just a little bit but not, kind of, decisively.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, you asked me about fiscal policy and the connection to productivity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think in the tax bill there’s—there are incentives for—there—a tax cut bill that allows expensing of investments should encourage additional investment that should encourage productivity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In theory, an individual tax bill that lowers tax rates should encourage more labor force participation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I do think it’s very important that we have a focus on productivity in the country.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s not something that we can really do at the Fed, but, you know, we’re certainly hopeful that there will be supply-side effects like that from the tax bill.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think estimates are really all over the place in terms of the amount and the timing of those.

speaker: JONATHAN SPICER
sentence: Chairman Powell, Jonathan Spicer with Reuters.

speaker: JONATHAN SPICER
sentence: I take your caveats on the dot plot, as it were, but I’ll ask another question.

speaker: JONATHAN SPICER
sentence: In 2020, it shows that policymakers expect the policy rate to get up almost to 3½ percent, which is quite a ways—or, March 21, 2018 definitively, anyways—above the neutral rate.

speaker: JONATHAN SPICER
sentence: Does that increase the risk of a Fed-induced Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL recession and decrease the risk of a soft landing?

speaker: JONATHAN SPICER
sentence: Which is asking, in a way, about the fiscal policy.

speaker: JONATHAN SPICER
sentence: And, as a follow-up, is that fiscal stimulus starting to lead to questions within the Fed around this narrative of secular stagnation and the economy entering a new sort of “low rates” environment?

speaker: JONATHAN SPICER
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, I would say that—remember that forecasts three years out—so, you’re right, in 2020 there’s a—I think it’s 3.4 percent is the median of the SEP dots for 2020, which is 40 basis points above the estimates of the neutral rate, which I would characterize as, you know, modestly restrictive, modestly tightening policy, but that’s three years in the future.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we don’t have the ability to see that far into the future, so I really wouldn’t put a lot in that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It could make sense.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You could imagine narratives in which that would make sense, but I honestly I wouldn’t put too much on that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Sorry, your second question was?

speaker: JONATHAN SPICER
sentence: The second question was whether the secular stagnation narrative—whether fiscal policy is being questioned by the Fed around that?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ve been through many years of growth around 2 percent, and I’ve given a number of public remarks where I’ve called on, you know, the country to focus more on potential growth and productivity and labor force participation, which drive potential growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, you know, I think it’s really important that we do something—do what we can as a country to increase our potential growth rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would say in the bill that passed Congress, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, there were elements that should encourage productivity, as I mentioned—sorry, encourage investment, which should help productivity, encourage labor force participation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t know how big those effects are going to be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t know what March 21, 2018 the timing would be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think, as you look around the table at the FOMC, there’s a wide range of Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL views on the amount and the timing of those.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think all of us would agree that we hope that they will be large.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: Hi.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: Mike Derby from Dow Jones Newswires.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: I have a question about the future of the mechanics of monetary policy.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: I wanted to know whether you favor sticking with the system that you have now of keeping interest on excess reserves and reverse repo—the reverse repo rate to control interest rates—or do you want to shift back to the old way of doing things at some point of targeting the fed funds market?

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: And do you have any concern that if you do stick with the current system that, as rates rise, that you might see issues where the Fed is under—is being criticized for paying out ever larger shares of money to banks to, you know, to control interest rates that some might perceive as a subsidy to the banks that are getting this money?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Our current framework for implementing monetary policy is working very well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We have excellent control over rates, and it’s working.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And it’s—you described it accurately.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We haven’t made a decision to keep that as our longer-run framework.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We haven’t really addressed that question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve had meetings where we’ve talked about it, and we’ve agreed that it’s working well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But it’s—and it’s not something I see us as needing to urgently address.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think we’re continuing to learn about this framework.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: For example, one—in the long-run, the size of the balance sheet is going to depend on the public’s demand for our liabilities, including currency and reserves.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we don’t know what the demand is for reserves in a world where you have—you know, you have regulations that require banks to hold lots of high-quality liquid assets, and reserves are one of those.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it’s not something we’re looking at resolving in the near term.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You mentioned the question of interest on excess reserves, and I think it’s a little bit of a misnomer to think that there’s a subsidy there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We pay interest on excess reserves.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We can’t pay interest on excess reserves that are—is above the general level of short-term interest rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’re paying rates that banks can get from other interest rates from other—any other investment in the short-term money markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In addition, remember that those liabilities—those are our liabilities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The assets that we have on the other side are Treasury securities and mortgage-backed securities, which yield much higher than interest on reserves.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, in fact, it’s not a subsidy, and it’s not a cost to the taxpayer.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Over here.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you, Chairman.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Greg Robb from MarketWatch.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Several of your colleagues recently have been speaking and expressing concern about financial imbalances and rising signs of financial imbalances.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: I was wondering if you could give us your view on the asset markets.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Are—do you see any bubbles?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And do you have the tools you need, you think, to combat those?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Since the financial crisis, we’ve been monitoring financial conditions and financial stability issues very carefully, and the FOMC receives regular briefings about the staff framework and, sort of, measures of various aspects of financial—financial stability risks, and the current view of the Committee is that financial stability vulnerabilities are moderate, let’s say.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I’ll go through a couple of pieces of that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, if you look at the banking system, particularly the large financial institutions, you see higher capital.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You see much higher liquidity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You see them more aware of their risks and better able to manage them with stress testing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And if one—if something does go wrong, you’ve got—you’ve got better ability to deal with the failure of those institutions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, therefore, you don’t see high leverage.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You don’t see excess risk-taking in great quantity the way you did see March 21, 2018 before the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If you look at households, household balance sheets are in much better Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL condition.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If you look at nonfinancial corporations, you see—you do see relatively elevated levels of borrowing, but nothing that suggests, you know, serious risks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, of course, default rates are very low.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So those readings look okay.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I should mention also that for large financial institutions, they’re no longer funded by a lot of short-term wholesale funding, which can disappear very quickly, so they’re far less vulnerable to liquidity issues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Overall, those aspects, I think, suggest low levels of vulnerability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You identified the—really, one area where—which is an area of focus, which is asset prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, in some areas, asset prices are elevated relative to their longer-run historical norms.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You can think of some equity prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You can think of commercial real estate prices in certain markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But we don’t see it in housing, which is key.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so, overall, if you put all of that into a pie, what you have is moderate vulnerabilities, in our view.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In terms of whether we have the tools, you know, we have some tools, and I think we certainly—we use them.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We have—I think the stress test is a really important tool that we have for the largest financial institutions and for the smaller financial institutions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We regularly use that to—as a way to test against various, you know, market shocks, certainly for the larger institutions.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Hi.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Victoria Guida with Politico.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: More on the regulatory side, you know, the Fed might soon be getting more power to decide exactly which regulations—which stricter regulations to apply to banks with between $100 and $250 billion in assets.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: And so I had a couple of questions about that.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: So, for CCAR, those stress tests, since that’s based around, you know, having a punitive penalty of potentially being able to restrict dividend payouts or stock buybacks, is there any kind of logistical challenge that could be posed if you don’t have CCAR every year for certain banks?

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Is it possible to have CCAR not on an annual basis?

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: And then, my other question is, you know, you’ve talked a lot about how size isn’t the only thing that causes banks to pose systemic risk, and I was wondering, what other factors do you think would cause a bank to potentially pose a systemic risk?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, this is a matter that Congress has under consideration.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s not something—so Congress is looking at raising the threshold for applying enhanced financial standards to—from $50 billion to $250 billion, while leaving us with the ability to reach below $250 billion and apply those standards where we think it’s appropriate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we haven’t been shy about doing that, because, of course, one of the eight SIFIs is below 250 already.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we are fully prepared to do that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But this is a decision that’s in the hands of Congress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s not something that’s been—been taken.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The version of the bill, I think, that passed the Senate did have—did give us the ability to do supervisory stress tests periodically, as opposed to annually, is the language.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We haven’t made any decision about that at all.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We would want to think very carefully about that, and, you know, we would—whatever we do decide to do, we’d put that out for comment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Is it, you know, logistically possible?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would think it would be, but it’s certainly not something that we’ve decided to do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And the second question you had was?

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: About what causes banks to pose systemic risk beyond size.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Well, it’s—I guess the next thing on the list would be activities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we—regular way commercial banks that do deposit taking and lending and don’t speculate in markets, you know, that’s one business model.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Another business model might be, you know, if you think of a hedge fund, right?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s what they do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They’re speculating on markets, and—you know, so very different business models and different levels of risk and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, that’s—that would be the next thing on the list.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I mean, there March 21, 2018 would be a range of things, you know—how well capitalized is the institution, but mainly those Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL things.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Michael McKee from Bloomberg Television and Radio.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: I’d like to go back to the idea of the additional growth that you’re getting from the fiscal package and ask you how much you think comes from the supply side and how much from demand?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: You use words like “might” and “should” about what results should come from this process, but, around the table, did any of the presidents or Governors report that businesses are actually getting ready to spend?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Is this something that’s going to happen?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Do we know that there’s going to be a supply-side effect, or are you just guessing at this point?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Remember that there are 15 FOMC participants, and we—each of us has his or her own forecast.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So there’s a real diversity of views on this, particularly on these fiscal issues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If I could try to summarize, it would be that, I think, broadly speaking, participants believe there will be meaningful increases in demand from the new fiscal policies for at least the next, let’s say, three years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think there’s a general view as well that supply-side issues—that there could be supply-side effects as well, and you would see that again through higher investment, driven by lower corporate tax rates and the expensing of some investment, which would drive—tend to drive productivity over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If you make investment more attractive, companies should do more of it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s uncertain, though.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I mean, I spent many years of my life working with companies and discussing—and, you know, the cost of capital is one of many factors that they’ll consider.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It isn’t the only factor or the principle factor, but it should result in more investment, and investment should drive productivity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: At the same time, the—you know, I mentioned labor supply.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You should see some labor supply effects over time from lower individual effective tax rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The whole thing is very March 21, 2018 uncertain, and particularly the supply-side effects should and would be expected to take longer to Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL appear and would be less certain in amount.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s really as good as you can go.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’ve all looked at the literature carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve all thought about it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve discussed it with our in-house experts and come up with our own views, and they’re disparate, but that’s—I’d say that’s about where the—where the views are.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Donna Borak with CNN.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Just to go back to trade policy, if you don’t mind.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: You said that participants today generally are feeling that the trade policy shouldn’t necessarily affect the current economic outlook, but I am wondering if there was any discussion—if there are fears about inflationary effects, should there be trade barriers imposed?

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: And, secondly, you know, we might be on the verge of a tit-for-tat trade war with China.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Wondering what your thoughts are of how that might dampen the economic—the global economic outlook going forward should that occur.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, at this stage, what our FOMC participants discussed—it wasn’t—it was—it was just that this is a new risk that had been probably a low-profile risk, which has become, you know, a more prominent risk to the outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s really what people were saying.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They didn’t get into talking about particular—you know, whether it’s inflation or growth or whatever it would be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s not something that did come up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know—your second question, sorry, was China?

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Yes.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: I mean, in the event that the United States and China—in the event that the U.S. and China end up in a tit-for-tat trade war, or any other retaliatory actions that are imposed elsewhere against the United States, what that means for the global economic outlook, and whether that was something that was discussed and are you worried about.

speaker: CHAIMRAN POWELL
sentence: That didn’t—it’s not something that came up in particular.

speaker: CHAIMRAN POWELL
sentence: And, let me say, you know, we don’t do trade policy here at the Fed, and, you know, I would be reluctant to comment on any particular situation with any particular country.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer with Marketplace.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Does the interest rate hike today suggest that Americans are being paid enough?

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Are you satisfied with the rate of wage growth right now?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, you know, we’ve had unemployment decline sharply since, I guess, 2010, when it peaked at 10 percent and down to 4.1 percent now, and we’ve seen only modest increases in wages.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, on the one hand, what wages should in theory represent is inflation plus productivity increases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You should get paid for your productivity plus inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And productivity’s been very low.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Inflation’s been low.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So these low wage increases—in a sense, they do make sense in that—from that perspective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: On the other hand, as the market has tightened, as labor markets have tightened, and we hear reports of labor shortages and we see that, you know, groups of unemployed are diminishing, and the unemployment rate is going down, we haven’t seen, you know, higher wages—wages going up more.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I would—I think I’ve been surprised by that, and I think others have as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In terms of what’s the right level, I don’t think I have a view on what the right level of wages is, but I think we will—we will know that the labor market is getting tight when we do see a more meaningful upward move in wages.

speaker: VIRGINIE MONTET
sentence: Virginie Montet with Agence France-Presse.

speaker: VIRGINIE MONTET
sentence: If the economy behaves as the Fed is predicting, by the time of the midterm elections, the rates will be—keep on rising, and the prime rate will be above—well above 5 percent, a level not reached in 10 years for what is a base of consumer credit.

speaker: VIRGINIE MONTET
sentence: And we know that, historically, raising rates—especially March 21, 2018 in campaign times—has never been very popular in the White House.

speaker: VIRGINIE MONTET
sentence: Does this prospect of a Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL possible pressure and dichotomy of concerns keep you awake at night?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: No.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That doesn’t keep me awake at night.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t consider the election cycle.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we—we’re looking very carefully at our assigned responsibilities of maximum employment, stable prices, and that’s really our focus.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You can count on us to stay focused on the jobs that Congress has assigned us and count on us to use the tools we have to achieve them.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You’re right, that’s the highest rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: By the way, I’m hearing this, the 10-year thing a few times these days, and it’s true that rates are higher than they’ve been in 10 years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: On the other hand, the economy’s healthier than it’s been since—since before the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, it’s a healthier economy than it’s been in 10 years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The financial crisis, of course, was just really getting going 10 years ago.

speaker: MYLES UDLAND
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: MYLES UDLAND
sentence: Myles Udland, Yahoo Finance.

speaker: MYLES UDLAND
sentence: Chair Powell, I’m curious if the Fed would be willing to tolerate an inverted yield curve.

speaker: MYLES UDLAND
sentence: We continue to see the spread between the 2-year and the 10-year tighten, even with longer-term yields coming up since the beginning of the year.

speaker: MYLES UDLAND
sentence: This is a dynamic that has typically preceded recessions, and we’re likely to see shorter-term rates come up as the Fed continues to increase rates.

speaker: MYLES UDLAND
sentence: So, I’m just curious if you guys have discussed that, if you’d be willing to push back against that, or if that’s a dynamic you’d be comfortable with?

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s an interesting question, and there are a range of views there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think it’s true that yield curves have tended to predict recessions if you look back over many cycles, but a lot of that was just situations in which inflation was allowed to get out of control, and the Fed had to tighten, and that put the economy into a recession.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s really not the situation we’re in now, so I don’t know that that’s—I don’t know that—I don’t think that March 21, 2018 recession probabilities are particularly high at the moment, any higher than they normally are.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL But, having said that, I think it’s—there are good questions about what a flat yield curve or inverted yield curve does to intermediation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s hard to find in the research data, but nonetheless, I think those are issues that we’ll be watching carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Thank you very much.
